Yes, there have been efforts by some political parties and advocacy groups to promote policies that simultaneously address climate change and economic issues. This approach is often referred to as a "Green New Deal" and has gained traction globally in recent years.

In Australia, the Australian Greens have called for a Green New Deal that includes measures such as investing in renewable infrastructure, transitioning to a zero-emissions economy, and creating jobs through investments in education and training programs.

Similarly, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has called for a "just transition" to a sustainable economy that would prioritize the needs of workers and communities affected by the shift away from fossil fuels. The ACTU has argued that this transition will require government investment in renewable infrastructure and training programs to ensure that workers have the skills needed to transition to new green jobs.

There have also been calls for the government to incorporate climate change considerations into economic recovery policies. For example, the Climate Council has argued that investing in renewable energy and energy efficiency initiatives as part of the COVID-19 recovery will help create jobs while reducing emissions.

While these policies have gained support from some groups and politicians, they remain controversial and have faced opposition from some industry groups and political parties.
